The clock-bell tolls the hour of early day,</br>The lowing herd their Smithfield penance drie,</br>The watchman homeward plods his weary way,</br>And leaves the Fair, all solitude, to me!
Now the first beams of morning glad the sight,</br>And all the air a solemn stillness holds;</br>Save when the sheep-dog bays with hoarse affright,</br>And brutal drovers pen the unwilling folds.

Save that, where shelter'd or from wind or show'r,</br>The lock'd-out 'prentice, or frail nymph complain,</br>Of such as, wandering near their secret bower,</br>Molest them, sensible in sleep, to pain.

Beneath those ragged tents — that boarded shade,</br>Which late display'd its stores in tempting heaps;</br>There children, dog, cakes, oysters, all are laid,</br>There, guardian of the whole, the master sleeps.
The busy call of care-begetting morn,</br>The well-slept passenger's unheeding tread,</br>The showman's clarion, or the echoing horn,</br>Too soon must rouse them from their lowly bed!
Perhaps in this neglected booth is laid</br>Some head volcanic, oft discharging fire!</br>Hands that the rod of magic lately sway'd,</br>Toes — that so nimbly danc'd upon the wire!
Some Clown, or Pantaloon — the gazers' jest,</br>Here, with his train in dirty pageant stood:</br>Some tired-out Posture-master here may rest,</br>Some conjuring Swordsman — guiltless of his blood!
The applause of listening cockneys to command,</br>The threats of City Marshall to despise;</br>To give delight to all the grinning band,</br>And read their merit in spectators' eyes,
Is still their boast; — nor, haply, their's alone,</br>Polito's Lions (though now dormant laid)</br>And human monsters, shall acquire renown,</br>The spotted Negro — and the arm-less Maid!
Peace to the youth who, slumbering at the Bear,</br>Forgets his present lot, his perils past:</br>Soon will the crowd again be thronging there,</br>To view the man on wild Sombrero cast.
Careful their Booths from insult to protect,</br>These furl their tapestry, late erected high;</br>No longer with prodigious pictures deckt,</br>They tempt the passing youth's astonish'd eye.
But when the day calls forth the belles and beaux,</br>The cunning Showmen each device display,</br>And many an useful notice round he shews,</br>To teach the ascending stranger — where to pay.
Sleep on, ye Imps of merriment — Sleep on!</br>In this short respite to your labouring train;</br>And when this time of annual mirth is gone,</br>May ye enjoy, in peace, your hard-earned gain!</br>
